case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. a firm

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 319 of 1958 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 319 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 31 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 31 of 1956.

facts.text: The appellant is the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Commissioner of Income-tax and the respondent is a firm carrying on business in Bombay

facts.text: The respondent is a firm carrying on business in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent is a firm carrying on business in Bombay and the question for decision arises under the Business Profits Tax Act

facts.text: The assessment relates to the year of assessment 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment relates to the year of assessment 1949-50 and the chargeable accounting period was from November 13, 1947,

facts.text: The chargeable accounting period was from November 13, 1947, to October 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: the chargeable accounting period was from November 13, 1947, to October 31, 1948. On January 12, 1953, the Income-tax Officer issued

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued a notice under s. 11(1) of the Act on January 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1953, the Income-tax Officer issued a notice on the respondent under s. 11(1) of the Act in respect of the above-mentioned chargeable accounting period

facts.text: The notice was served on the respondent on January 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: which was served on the respondent on January 21, 1953. The respondent filed a return under protest.

facts.text: The respondent filed a return under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a return under protest. The assessment was completed by the Income-tax Officer on November 30, 1953.

facts.text: The assessment was completed by the Income-tax Officer on November 30, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment was completed by the Income-tax Officer on November 30, 1953. Against this order the respondent took an appeal

facts.text: Respondent appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on ground of four years limitation under s. 14.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the respondent took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on the ground that the respondent was not liable to Business Profits Tax because it was beyond the period of four years limitation under s. 14 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the plea.

anchor.surface_text: This plea was upheld by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The Income-tax Officer then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal confirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal and it confirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Tribunal stated case to Bombay High Court on two questions of law at instance of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant a case was stated to the High Court of Bombay on the following two questions of law - Whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to assess the assessee firm under the Business Profits Tax Act

facts.text: High Court answered both questions in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court modified the first question by deleting the words without having recourse to Section 14 of the Business Profits Tax Act and answered both the questions in the negative.

facts.text: Appellant came in appeal to Supreme Court on certificate of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the appellant has come in appeal to this Court on a certificate of the High Court.

facts.text: Messrs. Narsee Nagsee Co., Bombay is the assessee firm.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Narsee Nagsee Co., Bombay (hereinafter referred to as the assessee firm), are the respondents.

facts.text: Income-tax assessment for the same year completed on February 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the assessment for purposes of income-tax for the same year was completed on February 17, 1953.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld objection that notice invalid under s.14(1).

anchor.surface_text: The assessee firm then appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who upheld the objection that the notice was invalid under s. 14(1) of the Act.

facts.text: The Punjab National Bank Ltd. is intervener.

anchor.surface_text: A. Palkhivala, S. S. Shukla and Mrs Eluri Udayaratnam, for the intervener The Punjab National Bank Ltd.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 6, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. May 6. The Judgment of S. K. Das and J.L. Kapur, JJ., was delivered by Kapur, J.

facts.text: Hidayatullah, J., delivered a separate Judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J., delivered a separate Judgment. KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order
s. 11 1  of the Act in respect of the above-mentioned chargeable accounting period which was served on the respondent on January 21, 1953.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to assess the assessee firm under the Business Profits Tax Act by issue of a notice under Section 11 1  of the Business Profits Tax Act on 12-1-1953 in respect of the chargeable accounting period 13-11-1947 to 31-10-1948 without having recourse to Section 14 of the Business Profits Tax Act ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to assess the assessee firm under the Business Profits Tax Act by issue of a notice under Section 11 1  of the Business Profits Tax Act on 12-1-1953 in respect of the chargeable accounting period 13-11-1947 to 31-10-1948 without having recourse to Section 14 of the Business Profits Tax Act ?

issues.text: If the answer to Question No. 1 is in the negative whether the B. P. T. assessment could be considered to have been validly made ?

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to Question No. 1 is in the negative whether the B. P. T. assessment could be considered to have been validly made ?

issues.text: Whether both ss. 11 and 14 had to be read together and the mention of four years in s. 14 was an important indication of the period of limitation in regard to the issue of notice under s. 11 also

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did not accept this view. It held that both ss. 11 and 14 had to be read together and the mention of four years in s. 14 was an important indication of the period of limitation in regard to the issue of notice under s. 11 also and further if profits which

issues.text: Whether s. 11 applies to original assessments after the first notice calling upon an assessee to make a return in regard to the profits of any chargeable accounting period and s. 14 applies where such notice was issued, and it either ended in no assessment at all or there was under-assessment

anchor.surface_text: In other words, s. 11 applies to original assessments after the first notice calling upon an assessee to make a return in regard to the profits of any chargeable accounting period and s. 14 applies where such notice was issued, and it either ended in noassessment at all or there was under-assessment, etc.

issues.text: Whether income escapes assessment when the process of assessment has not been initiated as also in a case where it has resulted in no assessment after completion of the process of assessment

anchor.surface_text: These sections lead to the conclusion that every business to which the Act applies is liable to the risk of being assessed to Business Profits Tax and it is well settled that income escapes assessment when the process of assessment has not been initiated as also in a case where it has resulted in noassessment after completion of the process of assessment.

issues.text: Whether the provisions relating to escaping of assessment in the two statutes, i.e., in s. 14 of the former and in s. 34 1  of the latter as it existed after the amendment of 1939, employ the same language, they must receive the same interpretation

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Indian Income-tax Act are both taxing statutes operating on the same source., i.e., profits of business which is similarly defined in the two statutes. If the provisions relating to escaping of assessment in the two statutes, i.e., in s. 14 of the former and in s. 34 1  of the latter as it existed after the amendment of 1939, employ the same language, they must receive the same interpretation

issues.text: Whether a narrow meaning should be given to the words profits which have escaped assessment as denoting only those profits which by reason of a prior notice under s. 11 were sought to be assessed but had escaped assessment or a wide meaning to include those profits which were never sought to be assessed

anchor.surface_text: The question thus is whether a narrow meaning should be given to the words profits which have escaped assessment as denoting only those profits which by reason of a prior notice under s. 11 were sought to be assessed but had escaped assessment or a wide meaning to include those profits which were never sought to be assessed or brought under assessment by the issuance of a notice under S. 11.

issues.text: Whether in s. 11 of the Act a limitation corresponding to the limitation contained in s. 14 must necessarily be read

anchor.surface_text: The short question thus is whether in s. 11 of the Act a limitation corresponding to the limitation contained in s. 14 must necessarily be read.

issues.text: Whether the notice under s. 11 in respect of a chargeable accounting period should issue before the commencement of the next chargeable accounting period, and that if the notice was not so issued, profits must be considered to have escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal construed both these sections together, and expressed the opinion that the notice under s. 11 in respect of a chargeable accounting period should issue before the commencement of the next chargeable accounting period, and that if the notice was not so issued, profits must be considered to have escaped assessment, and that action could only be taken under s. 14

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to assess the assessee firm under the Business Profits Tax Act by issue of a notice under Section 11 1  of the Business Profits Tax Act on 12-1-1953 in respect of the chargeable accounting period, 13-11-1947 to 31-10-1948

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to assess the assessee firm under the Business Profits Tax Act by issue of a notice under Section 11 1  of the Business Profits Tax Act on 12-1-1953 in respect of the chargeable accounting period, 13-11-1947 to 31-10-1948, without having recourse to section 14 of the Business Profits Tax Act ?

arguments.claim: The assessment is barred by the four-year limitation period under s.14 of the Business Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the respondent took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on the ground that the respondent was not liable to Business Profits Tax because it was beyond the period of four years limitation under s. 14 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: It held that both ss. 11 and 14 had to be read together and the mention of four years in s. 14 was an important indication of the period of limitation

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court (Kapur J.) held notice under s.11 invalid as beyond 4 years, reading ss.11 and 14 together.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.11(1) must be issued before the end of the chargeable accounting period; otherwise, profits escaped assessment and s.14 applies within 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal construed both these sections together, and expressed the opinion that the notice under s. 11 in respect of a chargeable accounting period should issue before the commencement of the next chargeable accounting period, and that if the notice was not so issued, profits must be considered to have escaped assessment, and that action could only be taken under s. 14

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ssments after the first numberice calling upon an assessee to make a return in regard to the profits of any chargeable accounting period and s. 14 app

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court and Supreme Court (Kapur J.) rejected strict 'before next period' but accepted 4-year limit via inference from s.14.

arguments.claim: Both ss.11 and 14 must be read together; the 4-year period in s.14 indicates limitation for s.11 notices as well, making the notice invalid if issued after 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did not accept this view. It held that both ss. 11 and 14 had to be read together and the mention of four years in s. 14 was an important indication of the period of limitation in regard to the issue of notice under s. 11 also and further if profits which

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ssments after the first numberice calling upon an assessee to make a return in regard to the profits of any chargeable accounting period and s. 14 app

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court (Kapur J.) agreed, holding ss.11 and 14 read together impose 4-year limit on s.11.

arguments.claim: Sections 11 and 14 apply to different circumstances: s.11 to original assessments (no prior notice) without time limit; s.14 to escaped assessments after prior notice or process.

anchor.surface_text: It is submitted by the appellant that though ss. 11 and 14 may have to be read together, they apply to different sets of circumstances s. 11 applies to a case where the Income- tax Officer requires any person whom he believes to be engaged in any business to which the Act applies or to have been so engaged during any chargeable accounting period

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Under s. 5 the Act applies to every business of which any part of the profits made during the chargeable accounting period is chargeable to income-tax

arguments.court_reasoning: Kapur J. rejected, holding escaped assessment includes no prior notice; Hidayatullah J. accepted.

arguments.claim: Escaped assessment includes cases where no notice under s.11 issued (process not initiated) and where notice issued but no/under-assessment.

anchor.surface_text: These sections lead to the conclusion that every business to which the Act applies is liable to the risk of being assessed to Business Profits Tax and it is well settled that income escapes assessment when the process of assessment has not been initiated as also in a case where it has resulted in noassessment after completion of the process of assessment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , or to be otherwise liable to pay business profits tax, to furnish within such period, number being less than forty-five days from the date of the se

arguments.court_reasoning: Self-reinforcing; cites IT Act s.34 cases.

arguments.claim: BPTA and Income-tax Act in pari materia; s.14 and s.34(1) use same language on escaped assessment, must receive same interpretation including no prior notice cases.

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Indian Income-tax Act are both taxing statutes operating on the same source., i.e., profits of business which is similarly defined in the two statutes. If the provisions relating to escaping of assessment in the two statutes, i.e., in s. 14 of the former and in s. 34 1  of the latter as it existed after the amendment of 1939, employ the same language, they must receive the same interpretation

court_response_anchor.surface_text: profits of any chargeable accounting period chargeable to business profits tax have escaped assessment, or have been underassessed, or have been the

arguments.court_reasoning: Applied to hold wide meaning for escaped assessment.

arguments.claim: No limitation can be read into s.11 as legislature did not prescribe one; plain meaning applies to original assessments at any time.

anchor.surface_text: It is always a serious matter to read into a section what the legislature has not chosen to put there.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tence, oversight, negligence or any other cause as to cases where such numberice proved abortive or ineffective. Both are cases of escaped assessment

arguments.court_reasoning: Kapur J. held harmonious reading requires importing limit from s.14; Hidayatullah J. accepted literal view.

arguments.claim: s.11 applies to first/original assessments without time limit; s.14 only after prior assessment/process where escaped/under-assessed.

anchor.surface_text: The short question thus is whether in s. 11 of the Act a limitation corresponding to the limitation contained in s. 14 must necessarily be read.

arguments.court_reasoning: Hidayatullah J. answered no; Kapur J. yes via inference.

arguments.claim: Excess Profits Tax Act ss.13/15 identical but limitation removed, unlike BPTA; deliberate retention in s.14 limits escaped cases to 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 deals with the issue of a notice for assessment and s. 15 with profits escaping assessment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: assess or reassess such income, profits or gains and the provisions of this Act shall, so far as may be, apply accordingly as if the numberice were a

arguments.court_reasoning: Supports limit but not for original s.11 per Hidayatullah.

arguments.claim: s.14 words 'assess or reassess' cover no prior assessment (assess) and after prior (reassess); avoids anomaly of no limit under s.11.

anchor.surface_text: The language of s. 14 and particularly the words may proceed to assess or reassess the amount of such profits to Business Profits Tax support the contention of the respondent that it applies to cases of noassessment due to notice not being given as to cases of noassessment after notice was given and proceedings proved ineffective.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sment as to a case where there was numberassessment at all because numbernotice was issued under s. 22 2  of the Income-tax Act in other words, it inc

arguments.court_reasoning: Supports wide escaped assessment including no notice.

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Gokuldas distinguishes; s.72 limited to after s.59 machinery failed, unlike BPTA where s.11/14 same process.

anchor.surface_text: The language of these ss. 59 1 , 71 and 72 is differs it from that of ss. 11 and 14 of the Act. Section 72 was held not applicable because there would be two concurrent jurisdictions, one providing reasonable protection for the taxpayer and the other providing no protection which would be contrary to the provisions of s. 71.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tence, oversight, negligence or any other cause as to cases where such numberice proved abortive or ineffective. Both are cases of escaped assessment

arguments.court_reasoning: No dual jurisdiction issue in BPTA as s.14 notice treated as s.11.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.11 valid without time limit as plain words allow for any chargeable period; belief suffices, no definite info needed unlike s.14.
s.11 covers current and back periods without assessment year concept; escaped assessment only after prior process.

anchor.surface_text: Three classes of persons are there mentioned. They are a persons believed to be engaged in any business, b persons believed to have been so engaged in any chargeable accounting period, and c persons believed to be otherwise liable to business profits tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Hidayatullah J. uses to argue no limit on s.11.

arguments.claim: No need to import limit into s.11; literal construction, legislature chose no words for it.

anchor.surface_text: It is always a serious matter to read into a section what the legislature has not chosen to put there.

holdings.text: Sections 11 and 14 of the Business Profits Tax Act have to be read together and the mention of four years in s.14 imposes a limitation on notices under s.11.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right when it held that ss. 11 and 14 of the Act have to be read together. The Act and the Indian Income-tax Act are both taxing statutes operating on the same source., i.e., profits of business which is similarly defined in the two statutes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction required; s.14's 4-year limit indicates overall limitation period for initiation of assessments to avoid anomaly of unlimited s.11 notices.

holdings.text: Profits escape assessment where process not initiated (no notice under s.11) as well as where notice issued but no/under-assessment.

anchor.surface_text: These sections lead to the conclusion that every business to which the Act applies is liable to the risk of being assessed to Business Profits Tax and it is well settled that income escapes assessment when the process of assessment has not been initiated as also in a case where it has resulted in noassessment after completion of the process of assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled from IT Act precedents; applies to BPTA via similar language.

holdings.text: Provisions of BPTA s.14 and IT Act s.34(1) (post-1939) employ same language on escaped assessment and must receive same interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Indian Income-tax Act are both taxing statutes operating on the same source., i.e., profits of business which is similarly defined in the two statutes. If the provisions relating to escaping of assessment in the two statutes, i.e., in s. 14 of the former and in s. 34 1  of the latter as it existed after the amendment of 1939, employ the same language, they must receive the same interpretation

holdings.reasoning_summary: In pari materia statutes on same subject (business profits) construed similarly; legislature adopted IT Act language.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer had no jurisdiction to issue notice under s.11(1) on 12-1-1953 for chargeable period ending 31-10-1948; beyond 4-year limit.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the assessment which was sought to be made was without jurisdiction and the appeal must, therefore, fail. We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice issued over 4 years after period end; s.11 limited by s.14; escaped assessment includes no prior notice, but time-barred under s.14.

holdings.text: BPT assessment not validly made as notice under s.11 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the assessment which was sought to be made was without jurisdiction and the appeal must, therefore, fail. We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid initiation under s.11 renders entire assessment void.

holdings.text: Words 'assess or reassess' in s.14 cover both no prior assessment (assess) and prior ineffective process (reassess).

anchor.surface_text: The language of s. 14 and particularly the words may proceed to assess or reassess the amount of such profits to Business Profits Tax support the contention of the respondent that it applies to cases of noassessment due to notice not being given as to cases of noassessment after notice was given and proceedings proved ineffective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation avoids anomaly of unlimited s.11 alongside limited s.14.

holdings.text: Retention of 4-year limit in BPTA s.14 (unlike EPTA s.15 amendment deleting limit) deliberate to bar escaped assessments after 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 deals with the issue of a notice for assessment and s. 15 with profits escaping assessment. Before the Income Tax and Excess Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1947 Act 22 of 1947 , there was a 5 years period of limitation prescribed in s. 15

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history shows purposeful difference from contemporaneous EPTA.

holdings.text: Gokuldas case distinguished; no dual jurisdiction issue in BPTA as s.14 notice treated as s.11.

anchor.surface_text: The language of these ss. 59 1 , 71 and 72 is differs it from that of ss. 11 and 14 of the Act. Section 72 was held not applicable because there would be two concurrent jurisdictions, one providing reasonable protection for the taxpayer and the other providing no protection which would be contrary to the provisions of s. 71.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different statutory scheme; BPTA ss.11/14 integrated process.

holdings.text: s.11 applies to original assessments without time limit; s.14 only to escaped after prior process (dissent).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal construction; no import limitation into s.11; different fields for ss.11/14 to avoid overlap.

holdings.text: No assessment year concept in BPTA; s.11 covers current and back periods without limit (dissent).

anchor.surface_text: Three classes of persons are there mentioned. They are a persons believed to be engaged in any business, b persons believed to have been so engaged in any chargeable accounting period, and c persons believed to be otherwise liable to business profits tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.11 classes; distinguishes IT Act scheme; EPTA supports no limit.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Pirojbai Contractor 1

anchor.surface_text: Both are cases of escaped assessment Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Pirojbai Contractor 1 . In this Court these words were companysidered and interpreted in Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Pirojbai Contractor
precedents.cited_proposition: escaping income applicable to cases where no notice under s.22(2) or notice but no assessment
precedents.cited_holding: Both are cases of escaped assessment

precedents.citation: Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2

anchor.surface_text: interpreted in Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2 . They were interpreted to companyrise a case of numbernotice being given for the assessment and numberice being given and resulting in numberassessment

precedents.case_name: Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of 'escaped assessment' in s.34(1) IT Act includes cases of no notice or ineffective notice
precedents.cited_holding: even in a case where a return has been submitted, if the Income-tax Officer erroneously fails to tax a part of assessable income, it is a case where the said part of the income has escaped assessment

precedents.citation: Maharajadhiraj Sir Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: quoted with approval in another case by this Court in Maharajadhiraj Sir Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar 1   per Hidayatullah, J. . Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2

precedents.case_name: Maharajadhiraj Sir Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: approval of Kamal Singh on escaped assessment

precedents.citation: Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. . Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2  was a somewhat different case. There assessment proceedings had been taken but had failed to result in a valid assessment

precedents.case_name: Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: assessment proceedings failed due to lacuna not attributable to authorities is escaped assessment
precedents.cited_holding: held to be a case of chargeable income escaping assessment and not a case of mere no assessment of income-tax

precedents.citation: Adam Haji Dawood Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma 1

anchor.surface_text: s. 50 because the two sections have to be read together and the assessee must apply for the refund within the period specified by s. 50 Adam Haji Dawood Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma 1

precedents.case_name: Adam Haji Dawood Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma
precedents.cited_proposition: ss.48 and 50 of IT Act to be read together

precedents.case_name: Gokuldas Ratanji Mandavia v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Indian Income-tax Act are both taxing statutes operating on the same source., i.e., profits of business which is similarly defined in the two statutes. If the provisions relating to escaping of assessment in the two statutes, i.e., in s. 14 of the former and in s. 34 1  of the latter as it existed after the amendment of 1939, employ the same language, they must receive the same interpretation
